June 28, 2009: Fiction
RELENTLESS, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $27.) A writer is pursued by a
sociopathic critic.
THE PHYSICK BOOK OF DELIVERANCE DANE, by Katherine Howe. (Voice,
$25.99.) A graduate student is caught up in her research on a healer accused of
witchcraft in Salem.
THE BOURNE DECEPTION, by Eric Van Lustbader. (Grand Central, $27.99.)
Robert Ludlum’s character Jason Bourne helps to avert a possible world war.
THE SCARECROW, by Michael Connelly. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) A Los Angeles
Times reporter tracks a devious killer.
MEDUSA, by Clive Cussler and Paul Kemprecos. (Putnam, $27.95.) In the eighth
NUMA Files novel, Kurt Austin and his team confront a Chinese crime syndicate
and a deadly virus.
SKIN TRADE, by Laurell K. Hamilton. (Berkley, $26.95.) Investigating some
killings in Las Vegas, the vampire hunter Anita Blake must contend with the power
of the weretigers.
SHANGHAI GIRLS, by Lisa See. (Random House, $25.) Two Chinese sisters in
the 1930s are sold as wives to men from California, and leave their war-torn
country to join them.
ROADSIDE CROSSES, by Jeffery Deaver. (Simon & Schuster, $26.95.) A
California kinesics expert pursues a killer who stalks victims using information
they’ve posted online.
GONE TOMORROW, by Lee Child. (Delacorte, $27.) Jack Reacher discovers a
conspiracy dating back to the Soviet war in Afghanistan.
MATTERS OF THE HEART, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $27.) A New York
photographer falls in love with a sociopathic novelist who lures her to his isolated
Irish estate.
THE 8TH CONFESSION, by James Patterson and Maxine Paetro. (Little, Brown,
$27.99.) Detective Lindsay Boxer and the Women’s Murder Club investigate a pair
of killings.
DEAD AND GONE, by Charlaine Harris. (Ace, $25.95.) Sookie Stackhouse
searches for the killer of a werepanther.
THE HOST, by Stephenie Meyer. (Little, Brown, $25.99.) Aliens have taken
control of the minds and bodies of most humans, but one woman won’t surrender.
WICKED PREY, by John Sandford. (Putnam, $27.95.) The Minneapolis detective
Non-Fiction
LIBERTY AND TYRANNY, by Mark R. Levin. (Threshold Editions, $25.) A
conservative manifesto from a talk-show host and president of Landmark Legal
Foundation.
HORSE SOLDIERS, by Doug Stanton. (Scribner, $28.) A small group of Special
Forces soldiers fought the Taliban on horseback shortly after 9/11.
OUTLIERS, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Why some people
succeed — it has to do with luck and opportunity — from the author of “Blink.”
RENEGADE, by Richard Wolffe. (Crown, $26.) The rise of Barack Obama, based
on the author’s coverage of the campaign and on a dozen interviews.
PRAIRIE TALE, by Melissa Gilbert. (Simon Spotlight Entertainment, $26.)
Overcoming substance abuse and bad relationships, by the star of "Little House
on the Prairie."
A BOLD FRESH PIECE OF HUMANITY, by Bill O’Reilly. (Broadway, $26.) The
Fox News commentator on his upbringing and career.
THE LAST BEST HOPE, by Joe Scarborough. (Crown Forum, $26.) Advice for the
Republicans and for America, from the host of MSNBC’s “Morning Joe,” a former
congressman.
HOME GAME, by Michael Lewis. (Norton, $23.95.) A reluctant father cottons to
his offspring.
ALWAYS LOOKING UP, by Michael J. Fox. (Hyperion, $25.99.) Fox’s last 10
years; his struggles with Parkinson’s disease and his work as an activist through
his foundation.
THE GIRLS FROM AMES, by Jeffrey Zaslow. (Gotham, $26.) An enduring
friendship among a group of Midwestern women.
SOUL SURVIVOR, by Andrea Leininger and Bruce Leininger with Ken Gross.
(Grand Central, $24.99.) The authors discover that their young son is reliving the
life of a deceased World War II fighter pilot.
HOW THE MIGHTY FALL, by Jim Collins. (Jim Collins/HarperCollins, $23.99.)
Companies fail in stages, and their decline can be detected and reversed.
RESILIENCE, by Elizabeth Edwards. (Broadway, $22.95.) Dealing with life’s
challenges, including cancer and her husband’s infidelity.
MY REMARKABLE JOURNEY, by Larry King with Cal Fussman. (Weinstein,
$27.95.) From Depression-era Brooklyn to “Larry King Live.”
